poem:
"Orchard Choices"

Ladders no longer needed
to pluck from the Apple.
Brussels shifts the branches,
guiding our reach.

Apps fall like autumn leaves,
unfettered from the Store.
Multiplying browsers,
alternatives pour.

No longer tethered 
to the singular Pay -
a shifting system,
choice has its say.

Hand picked choice,
freedom's installation.
A new kind of orchard,
bears the fruit of variation.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Apple to allow EU customers to download apps without using App Store Apple is to allow EU customers to download apps without going through its own store, as the iPhone maker adapts to new Brussels laws. Under the changes the US tech company will also give iPhone users a range of browsers to choose from as their default, allow the use of alternative payment systems to Apple Pay, and permit the installation of alternatives to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
